article.title: From an Action Principle for Action-dependent Lagrangians toward non-conservative Gravity: accelerating Universe without dark energy

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 displays the isotropic scale factor R(t) for a Universe filled with a perfect fluid in a matter-dominated era (γ=0) and a strong radiation-dominated era (γ=1). What is the most important consequence of the constant cosmological four-vector λμ on the expansion of the Universe?
choices: It causes the Universe to collapse for both matter and radiation-dominated eras.
It has negligible impact on the expansion rate for both matter and radiation-dominated eras.
It leads to an accelerated expansion rate for λμ < 0 without the need for dark energy.
It halts the expansion of the Universe at a finite time for both matter and radiation-dominated eras.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (25) presents the generalized gravitational field equation derived in the paper. What is the significance of the term Κμν in this equation?
choices: It represents the energy-momentum tensor of the matter field.
It describes the curvature of spacetime due to the presence of matter.
It accounts for the non-conservative nature of the gravitational field when λμ ≠ 0.
It represents the cosmological constant, which can vary with spacetime coordinates.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (30) describes the behavior of the gravitational coupling constant G(t) as a function of time in this modified theory of gravity. What happens to the coupling between geometry and matter when  λμ > 0?
choices: The coupling strengthens with time, leading to a more dominant gravitational interaction.
The coupling remains constant over time, similar to standard general relativity.
The coupling weakens with time, potentially leading to a decoupling of matter and geometry.
The coupling oscillates with time, leading to periodic variations in the strength of gravity.

multiple_choice_question.text: Equation (26) describes the behavior of gravitational waves in this modified theory of gravity. What is a key difference in the behavior of these waves compared to standard general relativity?
choices: The waves always travel at the speed of light, regardless of their frequency or the value of λμ.
The waves can be dampened or amplified depending on the value of the cosmological four-vector λμ.
The waves are always stationary and do not propagate through spacetime.
The waves only exist in the presence of strong gravitational fields, such as those near black holes.
